H0.text: An inference is being made by the student who examined a rock sample and described it as having particles of various colors that were 1 millimeter to 12 millimeters in size.

H1.text: A hypothesis was being made by the student who examined a rock sample and described it as containing particles of various colors ranging from 1 millimeter to 12 millimeters in size.

H2.text: A prediction is being made by the student when he examines a rock sample and describes it as having particles of various colors ranging from 1 millimeter to 12 millimeters in size.

H3.text: An observation is what the student was making when they examined a rock sample and described it as having particles of various colors that were 1 millimeter to 12 millimeters in size.

A4.text: A prediction is a rigorous, often quantitative, statement, forecasting what would be observed under specific conditions; for example, according to theories of gravity, if an apple fell from a tree it would be seen to move towards the center of the Earth with a specified and constant acceleration.

A5.text: A prediction (from Latin prae- 'before' and dictum 'something said') or forecast is a statement about a future event or about future data.

A6.text: Rescher, Nicholas (1998). Predicting the future: An introduction to the theory of forecasting. State University of New York Press. ISBN 0-7914-3553-9.

A7.text: Tetlock, Philip E.; Gardner, Dan (2016). Superforecasting: The Art and Science of Prediction.
